awd_titl_txt: Reconstruction of Manufacturing Patterns through Elemental and Isotopic Characterization of Raw Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation, Drs. Laure Dussubieux of The Field Museum, Shinu Abraham of Saint Lawrence University, and Thomas Fenn of California State Polytechnic University-Pomona, will undertake interdisciplinary research to understand ancient trade and exchange in South Asia and around the Indian Ocean as well as the relationship of that trade to the development of social complexity in the region. Political and ecological changes as well as other factors have an influence on the exchange networks connecting different communities. The different industries around the Indian Ocean, which fueled the trade conducted in this region and beyond, had to adapt in terms of their location and the nature and volume of their production, to shifts in the networks connecting the different actors of the trade.  Through the study of the local glass industry, researchers will study how such an industry responded to changes in trade patterns around the region from around the mid-first millennium BCE to the late Medieval Period. At a time when India is witnessing the collapse of its traditional glass industry in favor of a more automated and less labor-intensive alternative, this project will provide new information about the roots of an activity on the brink of extinction and will provide new insights regarding the consequences of changing industrial landscapes in the modern world. This project integrates research and training of undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary research. Results of this study will inform future exhibits and education activities at the Field Museum which educate hundreds of thousands of K-12 children and more than a million of visitors annually. 

This collaborative effort will include the collection of potential raw materials used for glass manufacturing based on the geological nature of the soils and the archaeological or ethnographical evidence of glass manufacturing in the area. Elemental and isotopic composition of the raw material will be determined and compared to data collected for ancient glass. Assuming that each center of glass production would procure raw materials from a nearby source, the diversity of the geology of India provides the possibility of characterizing each production center with a unique elemental and isotopic signature that will be identical in the raw materials and the finished glass.

por.por_cntn:
The Indian Ocean plays an important role in our contemporary world economy. It connects different regions via complex trade networks that are built on more than two millennia of interactions among the many communities that have occupied this vast region. Around the Indian Ocean, glass beads have become a very useful tool to assess the involvement of different ancient communities in Indian Ocean trade. They also enable the dating of archaeological sites around the littoral, since beads are time-sensitive artifacts with different types associated with distinct time periods. With the project “Reconstruction of Manufacturing Patterns through Elemental and Isotopic Characterization of Raw Materials” funded by the National Science Foundation, we focused our attention on the glass beads manufactured in India, a key participant in the Indian Ocean inter-regional maritime exchange networks. Beads manufactured in India represent a large proportion of the beads traded in the past around the Indian Ocean. Our goal was to locate more precisely within India possible centers of ancient glass production and to understand when and how they operated. This was done by determining the elemental and isotopic compositions of raw material samples collected from various potential glass production locales, and then comparing that data with corresponding data from ancient glass artifacts. Similarities could indicate that the latter were manufactured where the former were collected and thus allow us tentatively to distinguish several subregions for ancient glass production such as southeast India and western Uttar Pradesh. Other regions were also investigated, such as Maharashtra where several ports handled the Indian Ocean bead trade. These samples did not produce a chemical signature compatible with locally excavated glass artifacts, indicating that the glass was imported from another Indian region. Our results suggest a complex Indian glass industry that was likely stimulated and shaped by external demand from elsewhere around the Indian Ocean. This glass industry was still very active until a few decades ago but foreign competition producing cheaper beads led to its ultimate collapse; it is therefore important to research its roots before they are completely lost to history and memory. This project also demonstrates the advantages of closely integrating archaeological and geochemical analytical expertise to research the past.
